perturbation.original_text: Customer or its designees shall, within a period of [* * *] after the date of physical receipt of any shipment of Product from Supplier, inspect the Product for any shortages or any defects or deviations of the Product Specifications (hereinafter "Out Of Specification") that would be apparent from visual inspections of the Product. In the event that Customer is of the opinion that the Product is Out Of Specification at the time of delivery, Customer shall, within [* * *] after the date of physical receipt of Product, provide Supplier with a written notice to reject the Product (a "Notice of Rejection"), which shall include a description of the grounds for rejection and copies of test reports and testing methodology conducted on the Product, if any. However, with respect to any Out Of Specification Product which would not be apparent from a reasonable visual inspection on delivery, including in the case of any hidden defects, such Notice of Rejection shall be provided to Supplier not later than [* * *].
perturbation.changed_text: Customer or its designees shall, within a period of [* * *] after the date of physical receipt of any shipment of Product from Supplier, inspect the Product for any shortages or any defects or deviations of the Product Specifications (hereinafter "Out Of Specification") that would be apparent from visual inspections of the Product. In the event that Customer is of the opinion that the Product is Out Of Specification at the time of delivery, Customer must provide Supplier with a written notice to reject the Product (a "Notice of Rejection") immediately, but no later than 24 hours after the date of physical receipt of Product, which shall include a description of the grounds for rejection and copies of test reports and testing methodology conducted on the Product, if any. However, with respect to any Out Of Specification Product which would not be apparent from a reasonable visual inspection on delivery, including in the case of any hidden defects, such Notice of Rejection shall be provided to Supplier immediately.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows a reasonable period for inspection and notice of rejection. The modified text demands immediate notification, effectively shortening the time to a potentially impossible timeframe of 24 hours. This is an unreasonable restriction and contradicts the general principle of providing a reasonable timeframe for inspection and notification in commercial contracts, potentially violating the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under US contract law. Also, it changes the timeframe for reporting hidden defects to immediately which is not reasonable and gives undue advantage to the supplier.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under US contract law; Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) principles requiring a reasonable time for inspection and rejection of goods.

perturbation.original_text:
Each invoice provided by Supplier to Customer under Section 10.1, to the extent accurate, shall be paid by Customer to Supplier within [* * *] after the date of the invoice to the extent that Customer does not reasonably dispute that portion of the invoice in good faith.

All payments will be made in U.S. Dollars by SWIFT bank transfer directly to the Supplier account as specified in the respective Purchase Orders.
perturbation.changed_text:
Each invoice provided by Supplier to Customer under Section 10.1, to the extent accurate, shall be paid by Customer to Supplier within 60 days after the date of the invoice whether or not Customer disputes that portion of the invoice in good faith.

All payments will be made in U.S. Dollars by SWIFT bank transfer directly to the Supplier account as specified in the respective Purchase Orders.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires payment within a reasonable timeframe after the invoice date, contingent upon the Customer's lack of a good-faith dispute. The modified text mandates payment within 60 days regardless of any legitimate dispute. This violates fundamental principles of contract law, which grants the customer the right to withhold payment of legitimately disputed invoices.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Basic contract law principles regarding dispute resolution and the right to withhold payment for legitimately disputed invoices.

perturbation.original_text: Supplier shall maintain adequate books and records and retention samples consistent with cGMP Requirements and any other Applicable Law and requirements of applicable governmental or regulatory authorities, in respect of test records, samples and associated support data for all batches of Product Manufactured by Supplier sufficient to substantiate and verify Supplier's duties and obligations under this Agreement for [* * *] from the expiration date of the respective Product batch.
perturbation.changed_text: Supplier shall maintain adequate books and records and retention samples consistent with cGMP Requirements and any other Applicable Law and requirements of applicable governmental or regulatory authorities, in respect of test records, samples and associated support data for all batches of Product Manufactured by Supplier sufficient to substantiate and verify Supplier's duties and obligations under this Agreement for a period of 6 months from the expiration date of the respective Product batch.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates record retention for a reasonable period to ensure compliance and verifiability. The modified text truncates this period to a mere 6 months. Per regulations such as FDA requirements, records for the manufacturing of pharmaceutical products must be maintained for a much longer period to ensure traceability and regulatory compliance. Shortening the retention period to six months will make it non-compliant with regulatory requirements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Current Good Manufacturing Practice (CGMP) regulations, FDA requirements for record retention, and other applicable regulatory standards mandating adequate retention periods for pharmaceutical manufacturing records.
